cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Port Said Febuary 10

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.

div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, will leave Suez about January 30th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, will leave Port Said about January 26th.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0

Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express Steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wedensday for Port Sudan (and Suakin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe service to Kharteum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.
For freight or passage apply the Co.'s agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, or for passage only to THOS, COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE, REISE-BUREAT or other Tourist Agenecies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular Service fortnightly from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP ; every 4 weeks from BORDEAUX direct to ALEXANDRIA; homewards every 2 weeks from ALEXANDRIA for ROTTERDAM and HAMBERG. Goods forwarded at through rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Landing to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, etc. Special rates facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc. from ALEXANDRIA via ROTTERDAM and HAMBERG to German Manufacturing towns. For tarif and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS. Alexandria Agent.
The Following expected at Alexandria :
S.S. Androos Feb 6 from Hamburg bound for Beyrout.

S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, Febuary 4th, to be followed by S.S. Menepthah.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID every fortnight for ALGLERS and LONDON or LIVERPOOL.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. AMARAPOORA 6600 Tons Burthen sails from PORT SAID for Alglers & Liverpool about 31st January
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons Burthen sailing from PORT SAID for Alglers and Devonport about 10th Febuary
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons Burthen sails from Alexandria for Alglers & Liverpool about 24th Febuary.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL in 13 days.
The Saloon accommodations is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electric Light , and have all the latest improvements.
For further information Apply to the Company's Agents WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: PETER'S THE ORIGINAL MILK-CHOCOLATE
div.p: DIPETER INVENTOR
VEVEY SWITZERLAND
THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.
N. SPATHIS, Agent.
CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA.

BEAUTIFU ROOF GARDEN AND RESTAURANT.
BUCHER DURRER, Proprietor.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh – most charming Seaside Residence in Egypt
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais" tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort. Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
Telegraphic Address: BEAURIVAGE, Ramleh. – Telephone: 186, Ramleh. G. & M. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: SAVOY PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: STRICTLY FIRST CLASS
RESTAURANT AND ANGLO-AMERICAN BAR.
OPEN TO NON-RESIDENTS.

div.head: ENA HOUSE HOTEL,
div.p: GEORGE NUNGOVICH EGYPTIAN HOTELS CO.
(NEAR THE PYRAMIDS)
High Class Hotel. Private Dairy. Horses. Donkeys, Camels for hire. Golf. Tennis. Croquet

div.head: GRAND HOTEL, KHARTOUM.
div.p: The only First Class Hotel at Khartoum, prettily situatied in its extensive Palm Gardens on the Banks of teh Blue Nile, with commanding view from the terrace of the Hotel ove the Bluw and White Nile, Omdornian, and the Battlefields of Kerreb.
Entirely re-built. enlarged and refurbished in 1906; replete with all modern European comforts.
Electric Light, Stream Laundry, Lawn-Tennis, Stabling, Boating, own farm and Dairy products
Cosmopolitan Cuisine, European service.
Terms:-- From P.T. 100 to 125 per person and per day Special term for a prolonged stay
G. OTTO BOOK Manager

div.head: "AL HAYAT" Helouan
div.p: First Class Health Resort
Unrivalled Position on the Mokattam Hills
96 metres above the level of the Nile, surrounded by desert.
All rooms full south with sheltered verandahs
Public Sitting Rooms in separate Pavilions communicating by glass corridors.
Electric Light–Steam-Heating–Lift.
Bathing, Air and Diet Cures. Resident Medical Director. All kinds of sports. Own stables. Omnibus meets all Trains.
Ilustrated Prospectus sent free on appplication

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S HOTEL
div.p: THE PREMIER HOTEL IN EGYPT.
RESTAURANT & GRILL-ROOM OPEN ALSO FOR RESIDENTS
Motor-car running to Ghezireh Palace, and vice-versa

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.–Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and old baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling , dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate Charges.
Medical Resident Director: Arthur J.M. Bentley, M.D. –Town Office at Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
26 56-31-3-908 P.E HERGEL, MANAGER

div.head: ZANDER INSTITUTE,
div.p: HELOUAN, Opposite "Al-Hayat."
Under the Management of Dr. W. Preminger, from MARIENBAD. Will be open in January next, Medico-Mechanical Massage, Rontgen Rays, etc.

div.head: REISER & BINDER
div.p: Photographers. Photographers.
Alexandria & Cairo.

div.head: Sudan Express Mail Service (Via Suez and Port Sudan) Three Days to Khartoum
div.p: By KHEDIVIAL MAIL EXPRESS S.S. “PRINCE ABBAS” and “EL KAHIRA”™ and SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS “Trains de Luxe.” Devpartures from SUEZ DOCKS every WEDNES DAY 5 pm. after arrival of 11 am. Train from Cairo, with Through Carriages to alongside steamer Special Sudan Government Train de Luxe with Sleeping and Dining Cars, awaits steamer’s arrival at PORT SUDAN, FRIDAY EVENINGS, arriving KHARTOUM 8 pm. SATURDAYS.

Returning from KHARTOUM, the Special Train Leaves TUESDAYS 915 p.m. arriving alongside steamer at PORT SUDAN WEDNESDAY EVEN INGS. Steamer is timed to reach SUEZ SATUR DAYS to connect with 5:40 p.m. train to Cairo,

Farther particulars may be obtained from any of KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE'S Agencies or from Principal Tourist Agencies by whom Circular Tickets are issued to Khartoum by the Nile, returning by Red Sea Express Service or Vice Versa.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)
THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE” IS PRINTED ON PAPER MANUFACTURED AND SUPPLIED BY THE LONDON PAPER MILLS Co., LIMITED (SALES OFFICE: 27, CANNON STREET, E.C.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
THURSDAY, JANUARY 30, 1908.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM
div.p: The following extract is from the interesting lecture on "The White Nile and the Cotton Crop", delivered by Sir William WilloockK.C.MG FRGS, in continuation of his lecture delivered on 27th Dec. 1907, at a meeting of the Khedivial Geographical Society on Saturday. Sir William looks to the construction of a barrage at the point of junction of the Blue and White Niles at Khartoum as the most necessary engineering effort wbiob onald be made to save Egypt from the disastrous effects of a low Nile, which though considerably reduced since the construction of the Assouan dam are still a menace to the country. For a sum of less than LE 8,000,000, he affirms that works sufficient for the storing of three milliards of cubic metres of water would be complisher, and the Assuan tr servoir surpasword many times. Toe pasag dealing with the raining of the Dam is as
follows:

Out of the six milliards cubic metres of water needed for Egypt, the Assouan reservoir will be in a position to supply two For the other four milliards we have only to turn to tbo terminal reach of the White Nilo with

its wide channel about 1,000 kilometres long, with no slope in 500 kilometres and a slope of 1 100,000 in the remaining 500. Nature, which has, as a rule, been so niggardly in Africa bas opened ber lap to Egypt and given of ber good things with a tree hand. While Egypt needed lain in gation for 7,000 years, the muddy waters of the Blue Nile floud sopplied ber Lee's, arteri by the still more turbid waters of the Atba. Wben tw day we need to store clear water for the stater on a gigantic scale, the Wuite Vile is rewly with its reservoir-like bio to weet every neert of the country and of the Sudan.

Since giving my last lecture on the reservoir of the White Nile it has been pointed out to me that the late Sir Betijamin Paker only recommended the raising of the Assuan dam by 7 metres as a counsel of despair His opi Diuis contained in Blue Brok Egypt No. 7 of 1907, which appeared when I was ill and when no professional literatnre was allowed to enter my bands. I have just seen it. Here are his words: "If additional water is a national necer sity. I bave no hesitation in recommending that the raising and strengthening of the

ovan dam, in accordance with the designs submitted, be carried out, no alternative plan of a resonable and practical kind can, in my pinion, be deviser for storing the required quantity of water." Sir Benjamin bad dover seen the White Nile, and possibly the levels Wrre not then available.

The White Nile from Khartoum right op to Lake No is, as bas been already pointed out, very nearly a lake in flood and would stay lake for ever if the Blue Nile were subjeot to perpetual finod. Hetween low summer and high flood there is a difference of 8 metres. We want a masonry works which will keep this impounded water where it is when the Blue Nile has tailen, and deliver it just when we need it, pot superabundantly in the latter balf of Ootober, November and December, and in de ficiency in April, May and June, b. t vicerere A tarrage with 30 opening like the Esna bar. rage built at the poiut of junction of the Blue and White Niles, and holding op 4 metres of Water, aud & necond biber up the White Nile Dear, Gordon Tree, impounding furtber metres, would between them form a reservoir of extraordinary magnitude. The reservoir woull contain some three milliards of oubio metres of water, and would suffice fur Egypt and the Sudan for many years If this combination were not considered the best, a combinationof barrage at the junction of the Blue And White Niles with another at the Aba Zeid furd, would form a still more powertul reservoir. Then there in the Saubat mouth which is available. A combination of the three sites would bring us to the conceptions of the builders of the Pyramids and the construoton of Lake Mæris. Not only cald we store all the water veeded tor Egypt and the Sudan, but I believe we could bave such an effect on a very bigb Nile that the dangers of an inundation would materially be decreased. We are on the thres bold of as wonderful andas startling discoverins as any made by any hydraulic engineers in the world to begin with, three years would suffice to carry out the preliminary works storing three milliards of cubic, metres of water, while the onet would be under L.B. 3,000,000. The Assuan reservoir would be surpassed many times

But whatever works are carried out anywhere, the necessity of a reservoir at Assuno remains unaffected. This question was give into thor oughly, and this is the opinion we came to. I quote from my 1895 Report: "We have con cluded that it is absolutely necessary in the interest of irrigation to bave near at band, at the point where the Nile euters Egypt, a reserve of water to meet any contingencies which inight arina. There contingencies might arise from the fact that some of the more important su un mer crops are incapable of standing ten-days' drought, while the summer discharge of reservoirs bigh up the Nile would take many days to rowoh Egyps, and might sometimes be late in arriving"
